Description: Mould-made scaraboid in Egyptian blue; back in form of well-modelled Black African head, quite eroded, with short broad nose, thick lips and hair indicated by fine striations; underside incised with a representation of a winged lion (or less likely horse?); laterally pierced at hairline level; in bright blue paste.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Winged mythological creatures, either a lion or a horse here, are very popular on scarabs and scaraboids at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). It is depicted here in a rather hellenizing style. This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, see especially C13 for this piece). Though the back is a bit eroded, it is possible to recognise a Black African head rather than a Bes head (Gorton 1996, 126, C13). For similar scaraboids from Naukratis see: Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no.100 (BM 1886,0401.1666.A / EA 66493) and 145 (BM 1886,0401.1693 / EA 66515); Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 55 (BM 1888,0601.56 / EA35981) and 60 (Boston, Museum of Fine Artson 88.873). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 126, Type XXXIV C13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.03) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5779 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
